body: @ijuma Is 295 in http://jenkins.confluent.io/job/kafka_system_tests_branch_builder/ the one for this branch?
@guozhangwang yes, it is. The tests didn't run though, some issue with cluster resources not being available.
@ijuma @guozhangwang Looks like there was an issue bringing up the vagrant cluster in 295. I triggered another build here:http://jenkins.confluent.io/job/kafka_system_tests_branch_builder/296
Thanks @granders

Hmm, looks like changes to minikdc.py are potentially causing problems in other tests:
http://jenkins.confluent.io/job/kafka_system_tests_branch_builder/296/console

@granders what got you to say that the failures are due to the minikdc changes? I've noticed that previous runs also failed (e.g., 293), so I wonder if there is something else causing a problem, and I'm not referring to the ones that failed due to the vagrant cluster availability.

The only change introduced to `minikdc.py` is a space to the list of principals and I'm not sure how that would cause problems. If the list of extra principals is empty, there is an empty space at the end of the list.

@guozhangwang I would expect the underlying code that creates temporary directory to be the same in the current Java code related to KAFKA-2718 and the python code here. It will be good to get some more information for the unit test failures to figure out where the conflict is - I opened another PR to just add some logging.
@guozhangwang Notice the small bug in ConsumerCoordinator. We need to use a LinkedHashMap to ensure the order of the configured assignment strategies. Might be nice to pull this into 0.9.0.

@vesense The patch looks good to me overall. Since this patch requires adding an additional module to Kafka could you create a KIP proposal following this guidelines:

https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/KAFKA/Kafka+Improvement+Proposals

One example of a KIP:

https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=56852556

Once it is discussed and accepted, we can rebase this patch on trunk and merge it.
Hi @bbejeck , do you have time to address the minor comment, I am trying to merge this patch asap.

Hi @guozhangwang 

I thought I did that already, on last commit I removed the comments from the test.  Is there something else?

@ymatsuda Ping for another look. Some changes:
1. Added a Job Id config to StreamingConfig, which will be used as the group id and the default client id prefix if client id is not specified.
2. Override the consumer / producer / restore-consumer's client ids with some meaningful suffixes.
3. Removed ClientUUID, the reasoning is that client id could be set by users to make sure they are unique, if not we try to set it "in best effort" but does not guarantee uniqueness across JVMs.
4. The streaming client id is used in metrics as well as assignment member id as well.
5. Moved the change log validation as well as topics info into KafkaStreamingPartitionAssignor, and make PartitionGrouper light-weight.
You are right. Thanks! Merged to trunk.
Great, Thanks!

@guozhangwang Tests pass in branch builder:
http://jenkins.confluent.io/job/kafka_systest_branch_builder2/15/console

This went through a few rounds of review in a separate PR. Looks good to me, and replication tests pass here:
http://jenkins.confluent.io/job/kafka_systest_branch_builder2/16/console

@hachikuji good work spotting that bug. Would it be easy to write or modify a unit test to verify the behaviour? It's subtle and it seems overkill to have to run the system tests to detect it (the system tests are useful for other reasons, of course).

On a more general note, I think it's better to avoid methods like AbstractCoordinator.metadata() where we return a LinkedHashMap to indicate that ordering is important. It's too easy to make a mistake like the one fixed in this PR. I personally prefer using List for those cases as it's less error-prone (unless we really care about constant time get).

@granders I want to provide some justification for the last set of changes. Based on my local observations, there are two issues going on that are causing the failures we observed on jenkins. 

The first one is that if we always provide the Client/Server sections in the jaas file, then the client will spot it when we pass the jaas login file to the Kafka server and will try to authenticate with the ZooKeeper ensemble. The client will fail if the server isn't configured to do it because it'll keep waiting for the SaslAuthenticated event which will never come. I fixed this by making those sections of the jaas loging file conditional on the field zk_sasl.

The second issue is the one I mentioned to you offline about increasing the zookeeper connect timeout. Before I give evidence that increasing the timeout is necessary, let me give some background. In the client state machine of zookeeper, if the client isn't trying to authenticate, then it will receive a SyncConnected event meaning that client can start submitting requests. When trying to authenticate, the client needs to receive additionally a SaslAuthenticated event. Now let's check these log messages from a Kafka server while running the test case proposed here: 

```
[2015-12-03 11:11:31,914] INFO starting (kafka.server.KafkaServer)
[2015-12-03 11:11:32,084] DEBUG Initializing task scheduler. (kafka.utils.KafkaScheduler)
[2015-12-03 11:11:32,089] INFO Connecting to zookeeper on worker1:2181,worker2:2181,worker3:2181 (kafka.server.KafkaServer)
[2015-12-03 11:11:32,417] INFO JAAS File name: /mnt/security/jaas.conf (org.I0Itec.zkclient.ZkClient)
[2015-12-03 11:11:32,611] DEBUG Awaiting connection to Zookeeper server (org.I0Itec.zkclient.ZkClient)
[2015-12-03 11:11:32,611] INFO Waiting for keeper state SaslAuthenticated (org.I0Itec.zkclient.ZkClient)
[2015-12-03 11:11:34,553] DEBUG Received event: WatchedEvent state:SyncConnected type:None path:null (org.I0Itec.zkclient.ZkClient)
[2015-12-03 11:11:34,557] INFO zookeeper state changed (SyncConnected) (org.I0Itec.zkclient.ZkClient)
[2015-12-03 11:11:34,558] DEBUG Leaving process event (org.I0Itec.zkclient.ZkClient)
[2015-12-03 11:11:34,618] DEBUG Closing ZkClient... (org.I0Itec.zkclient.ZkClient)
[2015-12-03 11:11:34,817] DEBUG Received event: WatchedEvent state:SaslAuthenticated type:None path:null (org.I0Itec.zkclient.ZkClient)
[2015-12-03 11:11:34,826] DEBUG Closing ZkClient...done (org.I0Itec.zkclient.ZkClient)
[2015-12-03 11:11:34,837] DEBUG ignoring event '{None | null}' since shutdown triggered (org.I0Itec.zkclient.ZkClient)
[2015-12-03 11:11:34,837] DEBUG Leaving process event (org.I0Itec.zkclient.ZkClient)
[2015-12-03 11:11:34,845] FATAL Fatal error during KafkaServer startup. Prepare to shutdown (kafka.server.KafkaServer)
```

The client starts connecting around second 32 and it receives the SyncConnected event around second 34, barely making the timeout of 2s. If this client were not trying to authenticate, then it'd be fine. The SaslAuthenticated event, however, only comes after the timeout expires, which causes the Kafka server to shutdown.

It is possible that increasing the timeout is only necessary for my slow machine. I'm thinking of making ti configurable from zookeeper.py, but I wanted to start a new jenkins build to confirm that this makes sense.

Thanks for these improvements. As discussed offline, I think it would be helpful to clarify the impact of Kafka moving to 3.4.x at the client level (this could potentially mean issues if the ZooKeeper server remains at the 3.3.x level). It may be worth adding something to the upgrading page too.
Locally on my machine the test that fails on Jenkins (kafka.api.PlaintextConsumerTest.testCommitMetadata) passes, I can't reproduce the failure.
LGTM. Merged to 0.9.0.
Jenkins failures are not relevant, filed KAFKA-2943 to track it separately.
LGTM. Jenkins failures are not relevant. Merged to trunk and 0.9.0.

2. Add new admin (java) client: I plan to add integration tests here
3. Add new admin CLI (wrapping client)

`this.producerConfig.setProperty(ProducerConfig.ACKS_CONFIG, "1")`

@ijuma Testing all servers sounds better because the ACLs are propagated asynchronously via ZooKeeper, so I've made the change.

It turns out that the acks configuration where you commented wasn't really doing anything. The acks mode was hardwired in IntegrationTestHarness, so I've removed it and I've let it use the default of -1.

This PR LGTM.

Regarding how IntegrationTestHarness creates the producer and consumer via `TestUtils.createNewProducer` and `TestUtils.createNewConsumer` (changed as part of the introduction of `EndToEndAuthorizationTest`), I think this introduces a bit of surprising behaviour like we saw here (where the acks configured in the subclass was ignored). I think it would be good to rethink this in the future.
LGTM :+1:
LGTM. Merged to both trunk and 0.9.0.
Just to confirm: the test fails if topicBrokerReadAclArgs is not added right?

@ijuma yes, some of the test cases are supposed to fail in the case we remove that ACL. testNoProduceAcl doesn't fail, though, because the authorization to produced is refused before anything else. Interestingly, the failure is that there aren't enough replicas available:

```
org.apache.kafka.common.errors.NotEnoughReplicasAfterAppendException: Messages are written to 
the log, but to fewer in-sync replicas than required.
```

because it isn't possible to replicate without authorization, which we can see in the logs:

```
ERROR [ReplicaFetcherThread-0-1], Error for partition [e2etopic,0] to broker 
1:org.apache.kafka.common.errors.AuthorizationException: Topic authorization failed. 
(kafka.server.ReplicaFetcherThread:97)
```

Although not an issue foe this PR, it doesn't sound like a great way to expose the problem to the application in the case ACLs haven't been properly set, but at the same time, it is not clear how much of internals we want to expose. It is worth thinking about a better way to expose these errors, though.

Thanks @fpj, good to confirm. Good question regarding how to expose the error. Because the replication error is a server misconfiguration, my feeling is that we don't want to leak that to the clients. In that sense, NotEnoughReplicas seems fine. What I think we should do is to have a mechanism to validate the server security config (could be a tool or a start-up option, not sure).
@ymatsuda Add logic to exclude topics for KTables and use store name directly as topic name if loggingEnabled is false.
LGTM overall.

@rhauch Really appreciate your detailed description of your use case. So it seems your pipeline looks like this:

[data source] --> [input Kafka topics] ---> Service A / B / etc.. ---> [output Kafka topics, ...]

where:

1) Data source could contain "entities" (or in a another word, updates streams); and hence its ETL input Kafka topics need to be log compacted;
2) Service A / B / .. could be stateful processing and would prefer its input topic to be partitioned according to its inner state's key so each parallel processor can get all the records per specific key;
3) Output of each of the service A / B /.. needs to be sent to a single Kafka topicfor duplicate handling in exactly-once guarantees.

So it seems the issue we want to solve here is that for input Kafka topics, where we want to enable log compaction on the full message key for these topics while at the same time partition them with partial key for different services. What I was suggesting is that we can modify the pipeline as:

[data source] --> [log-compacted Kafka topics] ---> repartition service ---> [re-partitioned Kafka topics] --> Service A / B / etc.. 

where the "log-compacted Kafka" contains data ETL'ed from the data source and is log compacted with full message key, and a repartition service consumes from these topics and send them to another tier of topics by transforming the record <key, value> to <partial-key, value> with partial key as the partitioning key (with different re-partitioned Kafka topics their partial-key may be different, e.g. <database>/<collection> for one topic and <database>/<collection>/<table> for another topic, etc). So we separate log compaction with partitioning into separate tiers of topics. Would this work for your scenario?

BTW as you may know we are are now developing a high-level DSL called KStream on top of the Processor Topology API layer, where users can just use APIs like 

`KStream.from("source-topic").map(<key, value> -> extractPartialKey()).aggregateByKey(aggFunc)`

which will be translated to the underlying processor topology with re-partitioning automatically added to the topology, which will abstract users a lot more from the underlying Kafka integration such as partitioning, etc.
lgtm

@guozhangwang, that is a pretty accurate description of my use case. However, I still don't think that using separate tiers of topics provides the same functionality or guarantees. Not only are the extra tiers increasing the latency for completing each request (remember, my system is processing requests and delivering responses in near real time), but they may actually cause reordering of some requests of _related_ entities (e.g., all entities within a group or collection). Manually specifying the partitions minimizes the # of topics and services involved (and thus latency), and it helps me control total ordering of related requests.

> BTW as you may know we are are now developing a high-level DSL called KStream on top of the Processor Topology API layer, where users can just use APIs like
> 
> ```
> KStream.from("source-topic").map(<key, value> -> extractPartialKey()).aggregateByKey(aggFunc)
> ```
> 
> which will be translated to the underlying processor topology with re-partitioning automatically added to the topology, which will abstract users a lot more from the underlying Kafka integration such as partitioning, etc.

I am aware of the KStream DSL, and understood KStreams to be a way of implementing a topology with processing logic that could be represented as the provided simple functions (e.g., map, flatMap, branch, filter, windowing, etc.). Since my processor logic is complex (carefully using one or more state stores) to ensure exactly-once processing, that appeared to be well beyond the capability of KStreams and so I have not investigated it in much details.

Also, are you suggesting that a single KStream "program" might produce multiple topologies, or perhaps a single topology that uses intermediate streams not defined by the builder's `from(...)` and `sendTo(...)` methods? If so, is this documented anywhere?

LGTM.

LGTM overall. One general comment (may not need to be included in this PR) is that for some cases the client may want to receive the response not immediately after it is written to ZK, but until it has been successfully created (i.e. https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-1125).

Hence we may want to add another boolean field in the AbstractAdminRequest (where other requests like CreateTopicRequest extends from) indicating whether we want to be blocked or not.

I would like to model it asynchronously now, since the functionality is built that way today and then consider how to add blocking shortly after, but still as part of KIP-4. Whether thats done server side, or simulated client side is up for question at that point. Does that align with your thoughts?

@gwenshap Is KAFKA-2959 this related to KAFKA-1927 or just a dependent of it?

Ping @ymatsuda @junrao for reviews. General summary:

Top-level metrics with Kafka Streams are completely owned by Kafka Streams framework itself, and is not exposed to the users. They have the following format:

1) groupName = "streaming-metrics": e.g. in JMX it will be used as "type=streaming-metrics" in mbean name.

2) tags = ["client-id" => clientId + "-" + getName()], hence the tags client-id is distinguished per StreamThread.

3) metricName = "poll-time-avg", "process-time-max", "commit-calls-rate", etc.

A single thread containing multiple tasks will use a single set of sensors, and there is no differentiating across tasks within the thread.

---

Second-level metrics is exposed through the ProcessorContext.metric() API, in which users can add their own metrics. Today we only contain state-store operation latency metrics, with the following format:

1) groupName = "streaming-" + scopeName + "-metrics", where scopeName defines the store type, e.g. "in-memory-state", "in-memory-lru-state", "rocksdb-state".

2) no additional tags from the framework, i.e. still have one tag as clientId, while we have APIs for users to add more tags if they want while developing their own state implementations.

3) we define metric name based on the operation name and the "entity" name (i.e. store name for this set of metrics) , in two levels:

A global metric with metricName e.g. "all-put", "all-get", "all-delete";
A per-store metric with metricName e.g. "store1-put", "store2-put", .. etc where the global metrics' sensor is the parent of the per-store metrics' sensor.

With this, we still only define metrics per-thread, not per-task within the thread, but distinguish different state-store instances.
lgtm
